awd_titl_txt: Conference: Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
As the annual flagship conference of ACM SIGBio (Special Interest Group in Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics), the ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACMBCB) is aimed to provide an interactive forum that bridges computer science, mathematics, statistics, with biology and health. Its mission is to support
advanced research, training, and outreach. It brings together top researchers, practitioners, and students around the world to share innovative discovery, advanced development and delivery of informatics solutions to promote computational science, engineering for national health and biological advancement for societal impact. The ACMBCB2022 will be in Chicago IL during Aug. 7th-Sept. 01, 2023. This NSF grant will provide travel and registration support for up to 10 students (graduate, undergraduate, and high school) to attend the conference. The students will need to submit a short description about their on-going academic study and motivation for attending ACMBCB2022 (suggested to follow NSF Intellectual Merit, Broad Impact summary), plus supporting information such as a biosketch, a photo, and a letter of support from their advisor/mentor for selection. In addition, this NSF grant will broaden the diversity of participation from underrepresented groups (women, minority, and disabled) to enhance the community-building beyond the conference.

The 21st century is witnessing many transformations enabled by innovations happening at the interface of molecular biology, medicine, health, with statistics, computer science, data science, informatics, cloud computing, and AI. Thus, it is critical to cultivate the new culture when training younger generations. ACMBCB2022 will provide systematically organized activities such as workshops, tutorials, oral sessions, and poster sessions for researchers and practitioners from different disciplines to interact, to discuss, and to collaborate.  NSF support will maximize both learning and research outcomes of students. Not only they will learn novel advancements in bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics from the conference and improve their knowledge, but also they will share their own research ideas in Student Forum to gain visibility and feedback. In addition, because underrepresented minority groups (women, minority, and students with disabilities) have relatively low participation, ACMBCB2022 will continually promote diversity in participation through both Student Forum and “Women in Bioinformatics” organization. Senior researchers will be invited to provide feedback , and to share experience and wisdom in career development to continually build the community throughout the year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This ACMBCB2023 Travel Grant supported 19 students and young professionals to attend the 14th ACMBCB2023 in Houston, TX on Sept. 3rd-6th 2023 (https://acm-bcb.org/2023/), which is the flagship conference of ACM SIGBio (Special Interest Group in Bioinformatics). ACM SIGBio Board has made huge effort to bring this conference to in-person again after COVID19 pandemic. While developing synergy of the research on bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics is not easy, it is particularly challenging for underrepresented (URM) groups (women, minority, and people with disabilities).  The goals of this ACMBCB2023 NSF travel grant are to broaden the participation of young professionals and to broaden diversity of participation. This NSF award enables young professionals to meet distinguished speakers, to present their own research ideas, to discuss any new research problems, and to foster new collaborations within joint computational, biomedical, and health communities. It helps cultivate this interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research field.

The first key outcome is all the 24 applicants put in technical work to summarize their Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics related research, with both Broad Impact and Intellectual Property required by NSF. This practice alone has generated positive responses from both young professionals and their advisors.

The second key outcome the applicants presented in the NSF sponsored Young Professional Forum to share with the large research community. The research forum not only enabled these bright students and young professionals to exchange their research ideas, but also enabled them to gain visibility in the large bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics community.

The third key outcome is as a requirement for receiving this NSF travel award, these awardees attended the entire conference (oral and poster sessions) to interact with top bioinformatics and health informatics researchers during ACMBCB2023.

Another key outcome is the PI of this NSF grant Prof. May D. Wang organized Women in Bioinformatics (WiB) with seven panelists from academics, clinical centers, industry, and government lab both in North America and Asia to provide insights on promoting under-represented groups (woman and minority) in this interdisciplinary area. Many NSF awardees attended the panel and actively participated in the discussion about the challenges and opportunities in promoting diversity in bioinformatics and health informatics.    

Among 19 awardees, 9 are women and under-represented minorities.  The overall 47% women and under-represented minority awardees is the highest and encouraged their participation in ACMBCB.


Last Modified: 07/31/2024
Modified by: Dongmei Wang
